Summary of FastSLAM Paper

28 July 2021 - 3 mins read time
Tags: Robotics Computer Vision

Source: FastSLAM: A Factored Solution to the Simultaneous Localization and Mapping Problem

FastSLAM uses a modified particle filter to recursively estimates the full posterior distribution over robot pose and landmark locations. Compared to EKF-based SLAM algorithm that is in , well-implemented FastSLAM can be in in which M is the number of particles in the particle filter.

In SLAM problem, each landmark measurements are independent when we know poses and correspondence. FastSLAM decomposes SLAM problem into a robot localization problem and a collection of landmark estimation problems conditioned on robot pose estimation.

SLAM Problem Definition

  • Localization: estimation of pose from known landmarks
  • Navigation: estimation of pose, velocities, and other states from known landmarks
  • Mapping: estimation of landmark positions from known values of pose
  • SLAM: joint estimation of pose and landmark positions (localization AND mapping )

Robot Poses at Time t:

Robot Controls at Time t:

Landmark Measurements (range and bearing) at Time t:

Landmark Location in Space: for K immobile landmarks (points in the plane )

Correspondence (Index of Landmark):

  • Motion model

  • Measurement model

SLAM is the problem of determining the location of all landmarks ​ and robot poses ​ from landmark measuremnts and robot controls.

FastSLAM with Known Correspondences

  • Conditional independence of the SLAM problem implies that:

    which is a localization problem and K mapping problems.

  • The localization problem is solved by a modified particle filter

  • The mapping problems are solved by Kalman filters

Particle Filter Path Estimation

Use of a filter that is similar to the Monte Carlo Localization algorithm. MCL is an application of particle filter to localization. At each point of time, the algorithm maintain a set of particles . particle is a guess of the robot’s path at time t:

  1. Each particle in is used to generate a guess of the robot’s pose at time t:

  2. Set of particles in is distributed according to . The new temporary set of particle is distributed according to , the proposal distribution of particle filtering,

  3. New set is obtained by sampling from the temporary set. Each particle is drawn with replacement with a probability proportional to importance factor

Landmark Location Estimation

This estimation is conditioned on the robot pose, so the Kalman filters are attached to individual pose particles in . Hence, the full posterior is:

where are set of means and covariances of the Gaussian representing landmarks 1 to K attached to the m particle.

This is implemented using EKF. Compared to EKF-based SLAM, FastSLAM EKF only has a Gaussian of dimension two.
